articles.headline: Romney’s Tone on Gay Rights Is Seen as Shift
articles.snippet: The presidential candidate bristles when he is accused of shifting his views since his 2002 campaign for governor of Massachusetts.
articles.abstract: The presidential candidate bristles when he is accused of shifting his views since his 2002 campaign for governor of Massachusetts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney seemed comfortable as a group of gay Republicans quizzed him over breakfast one morning in 2002. Running for governor of Massachusetts, he was at a gay bar in Boston to court members of Log Cabin Republicans.

articles.headline: Hints of Progress, and Questions, in Iraq Data
articles.snippet: Military statistics show that U.S. forces have made some headway at protecting the Iraqi population, but there are questions over whether the gains can be sustained.
articles.abstract: Military statistics show that U.S. forces have made some headway at protecting the Iraqi population, but there are questions over whether the gains can be sustained.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 — For months, proponents and critics of the Bush administration’s strategy in Iraq have pointed to conflicting indicators about whether it has produced progress. The figures that have emerged in recent government reports have seemingly provided something for everyone.

articles.headline: Northern Overexposure
articles.snippet: With Canada saturated, the doughnut chain Tim Hortons is looking to the U.S. for growth, despite past difficulties faced by other Canadian retailers.
articles.abstract: With Canada saturated, the doughnut chain Tim Hortons is looking to the U.S. for growth, despite past difficulties faced by other Canadian retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKVILLE, Ontario — Tim Hortons conquered Canada long ago. The doughnut chain boasts one outlet for every 12,700 Canadians — by comparison, one McDonald’s exists in the United States for every 21,000 Americans and one Dunkin’ Donuts for every 56,000 Americans.

articles.headline: Bad News Puts Political Glare Onto Economy
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve could feel more pressure from Democrats and Republicans to cut interest rates.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve could feel more pressure from Democrats and Republicans to cut interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 — For the first time in four years, economic concerns are rivaling the war in Iraq as a top issue on the political agenda.

articles.headline: Stocks Tumble as Job Report Leads Investors to Shift to Bonds
articles.snippet: Investors sought safety in government debt and gold as the latest job report raised fears that corporate profits will weaken.
articles.abstract: Investors sought safety in government debt and gold as the latest job report raised fears that corporate profits will weaken.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares fell sharply yesterday and investors sought safety in government debt after a Labor Department report showed an abrupt drop in employment in August and raised fears of a recession.

articles.headline: Unexpected Loss of Jobs Raises Risk of Recession
articles.snippet: A Labor Department report showed that the economy lost 4,000 jobs in August, the first drop in four years, suggesting that turmoil in the financial markets could be spreading.
articles.abstract: A Labor Department report showed that the economy lost 4,000 jobs in August, the first drop in four years, suggesting that turmoil in the financial markets could be spreading.
articles.lead_paragraph: The job market took a serious and unexpected turn for the worse last month, raising the risk of a recession and putting added pressure on the Federal Reserve to move more aggressively to keep the ailing housing industry from infecting the rest of the economy.
articles.byline: By David Leonhardt and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Wyeth Loses Bout in Fight on a Generic
articles.snippet: A federal judge on Friday cleared the way for a copycat version of the popular heartburn drug Protonix.
articles.abstract: A federal judge on Friday cleared the way for a copycat version of the popular heartburn drug Protonix.
articles.lead_paragraph: The popular heartburn drug Protonix could face early generic competition, after a federal judge cleared the way for a copycat version of the medicine.

articles.headline: The Case of the Subpar Smartphone
articles.snippet: A “non-geek” recounts the trials and tribulations of owning a Treo smartphone made by Palm.
articles.abstract: A “non-geek” recounts the trials and tribulations of owning a Treo smartphone made by Palm.
articles.lead_paragraph: My Treo died.

articles.headline: Countrywide Plans to Cut Staff Deeply
articles.snippet: Countrywide, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, said Friday that it would lay off up to 20 percent of its workforce over the next three months.
articles.abstract: Countrywide, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, said Friday that it would lay off up to 20 percent of its workforce over the next three months.
articles.lead_paragraph: Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, said late yesterday that it would eliminate as many as 12,000 jobs, which would be the biggest round of layoffs in the troubled housing industry.

articles.headline: A Fugitive Political Fund-Raiser Leaves a Shadowy Money Trail
articles.snippet: At the center of the Norman Hsu mystery is the question of how he evolved from a bankrupt swindler to a wealthy political donor.
articles.abstract: At the center of the Norman Hsu mystery is the question of how he evolved from a bankrupt swindler to a wealthy political donor.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the center of the ever-deepening mystery of Norman Hsu, the fugitive fund-raiser who was captured after a brief flight from the law last week, is the question of how he evolved from a bankrupt swindler in 1992 to a wealthy donor to many Democratic candidates, and a bundler of campaign contributions to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2007.

articles.headline: In 2000, a Streetwise Veteran Schooled a Bold Young Obama
articles.snippet: Class emerged as a subtext during Barack Obama’s failed attempt to unseat an incumbent congressman on the South Side of Chicago.
articles.abstract: Class emerged as a subtext during Barack Obama’s failed attempt to unseat an incumbent congressman on the South Side of Chicago.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rise of Barack Obama includes one glaring episode of political miscalculation. Even friends told Mr. Obama it was a bad idea when he decided in 1999 to challenge an incumbent congressman and former Black Panther, Bobby L. Rush, whose stronghold on the South Side of Chicago was overwhelmingly black, Democratic and working class.

articles.headline: The Not-So-Simple Art of the Blood Test
articles.snippet: Only a few states require licensing for phlebotomists — it’s mainly on-the-job training.
articles.abstract: Only a few states require licensing for phlebotomists — it’s mainly on-the-job training.
articles.lead_paragraph: I RECALL asking the woman who was about to stick a needle into the arm of my 4-year-old daughter what she was: “Are you a nurse? A doctor?”

articles.headline: Can Michael Dell Refocus His Namesake?
articles.snippet: The founder of the former top PC maker is back in charge and rethinking the company’s orthodoxies.
articles.abstract: The founder of the former top PC maker is back in charge and rethinking the company’s orthodoxies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Round Rock, Tex.

articles.headline: It’s Time to Take a Deep Breath
articles.snippet: The subprime mortgage industry was far from an unmixed good, but it helped some people realize the American dream.
articles.abstract: The subprime mortgage industry was far from an unmixed good, but it helped some people realize the American dream.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHO would ever have dreamed that credit could be so thrilling? And yet tremors and shivers over credit, and especially over subprime mortgages, have led to some real panic in the financial markets, and rings of fire in the ventricles of the coldest-hearted financiers.

articles.headline: At Street Level, Unmet Goals of Troop Buildup
articles.snippet: The U.S. troop “surge” has slowed, but far from stopped, Iraq’s civil war, repeated visits to Baghdad neighborhoods show.
articles.abstract: The U.S. troop “surge” has slowed, but far from stopped, Iraq’s civil war, repeated visits to Baghdad neighborhoods show.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Stephen Farrell

articles.headline: Boys Cast Out by Polygamists Find Help
articles.snippet: Over the last six years, hundreds of teenage boys have been forced out of a polygamous settlement on the Arizona-Utah border.
articles.abstract: Over the last six years, hundreds of teenage boys have been forced out of a polygamous settlement on the Arizona-Utah border.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. GEORGE, Utah — Woodrow Johnson was 15, and by the rules of the polygamous sect in which his family lived, he had a vice that could condemn them to hell: He liked to watch movies.

articles.headline: Steve Jobs: iCame, iSaw, iCaved
articles.snippet: Steve Jobs insists that songs on iTunes cost 99 cents and television episodes cost $1.99 because consumers crave simple pricing. Except, of course, when it comes to Apple’s own products.
articles.abstract: Steve Jobs insists that songs on iTunes cost 99 cents and television episodes cost $1.99 because consumers crave simple pricing. Except, of course, when it comes to Apple’s own products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let me get this straight: Steve Jobs insists that songs on iTunes cost 99 cents and television episodes cost $1.99 because consumers crave simple pricing.

articles.headline: Still Married, With Children, but in Russian
articles.snippet: Despite the Kremlin’s drumbeat of anti-Americanism, Russians have embraced imports of American sitcoms.
articles.abstract: Despite the Kremlin’s drumbeat of anti-Americanism, Russians have embraced imports of American sitcoms.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Sept. 9 — Turn on the sitcom that is the hottest television show in Russia, and it all seems so familiar. Moored to his living room couch is a shoe salesman who is more interested in watching sports than conjugal relations. His wife has shocking hair and an even more shocking mouth. A couple of ne’er-do-well teenagers round out this bawdy, bickering bunch.

articles.headline: Disney to Test Character Toys for Lead Paint
articles.snippet: The move comes after three separate recalls of Mattel toys  were found to contain unsafe levels of lead paint.
articles.abstract: The move comes after three separate recalls of Mattel toys  were found to contain unsafe levels of lead paint.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reacting to three separate recalls of Mattel toys found to contain unsafe levels of lead paint, The Walt Disney Company said it would begin its own testing of toys featuring Disney characters, including random testing of products already on store shelves.

articles.headline: A Medical Publisher’s Unusual Prescription: Online Ads
articles.snippet: The international media giant Reed Elsevier hopes to pep up its lackluster medical publishing unit by giving away the latest articles from 100 of its own medical journals on the Internet.
articles.abstract: The international media giant Reed Elsevier hopes to pep up its lackluster medical publishing unit by giving away the latest articles from 100 of its own medical journals on the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: By some measures, the medical publishing world has met the advent of the Internet with a shrug, sticking to its time-honored revenue model of charging high subscription fees for specialized journals that often attract few, if any, advertisements.

articles.headline: Prisons Purging Books on Faith From Libraries
articles.snippet: Chaplains in federal prisons have been quietly carrying out a systematic purge of religious books and materials.
articles.abstract: Chaplains in federal prisons have been quietly carrying out a systematic purge of religious books and materials.
articles.lead_paragraph: Behind the walls of federal prisons nationwide, chaplains have been quietly carrying out a systematic purge of religious books and materials that were once available to prisoners in chapel libraries.

articles.headline: Warner Shifts Web Course, Shouldering Video Costs
articles.snippet: In its latest online push, Warner Brothers plans to introduce 24 Web productions in a range of formats including minimovies, games and episodic television shows.
articles.abstract: In its latest online push, Warner Brothers plans to introduce 24 Web productions in a range of formats including minimovies, games and episodic television shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 — In the race to become a major supplier of original video programming to the Web, Warner Brothers has decided to reverse its direction.

articles.headline: Rewriting Hollywood’s Rules
articles.snippet: Fresh off negotiating a landmark deal for the creators of South Park, the lawyer Kevin Morris is trying to build bridges between Hollywood and Silicon Valley.
articles.abstract: Fresh off negotiating a landmark deal for the creators of South Park, the lawyer Kevin Morris is trying to build bridges between Hollywood and Silicon Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 — Kevin Morris had just negotiated a landmark deal that set Hollywood buzzing, giving the creators of “South Park,” Matt Stone and Trey Parker, a precedent-setting 50 percent stake in the cartoon’s success on the Web and other emerging media.

articles.headline: Europeans Get Terror Training Inside Pakistan
articles.snippet: At least five of the suspects in a terror plot disrupted last week in Germany received training at camps in Pakistan.
articles.abstract: At least five of the suspects in a terror plot disrupted last week in Germany received training at camps in Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, Sept. 9 — The accused conspirators in a bombing plot disrupted last week in Germany were part of what the authorities say is a small, but growing, flow of militants from Germany and other Western countries who are receiving terrorism training at camps in Pakistan.
articles.byline: By Souad Mekhennet and Michael Moss
